message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Finite-Time Event-Triggered Control for Semi-Markovian Switching Cyber-Physical Systems With FDI Attacks and Applications
Paper Abstract: This paper addresses the finite-time event-triggered control problem for nonlinear semi-Markovian switching cyber-physical systems (S-MSCPSs) under false data injection (FDI) attacks. Compared with the traditional time-triggered mechanism, the proposed event-triggered scheme (ETS) can effectively avoid network resource waste. Considering the network-induced delay in the modeling, a closed-loop system model with time delay is established in the unified framework. By the use of a mode-dependent piecewise Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional (LKF), stochastic finite-time stability (SFTS) criteria are established for the resultant closed-loop system. Then, some solvability conditions are established for the desired finite-time controller in light of a linear matrix inequality framework. Finally, an application example of vertical take-off and landing helicopter model (VTOLHM) is provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the theoretical findings.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Event-triggered control"

Links: [{"title":"Time-triggered architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-triggered_architecture"},{"title":"Event (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystrokes"},{"title":"Time-Triggered Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-Triggered_Protocol"},{"title":"Maurice Heemels - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Heemels"},{"title":"DOM event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOM_Events"},{"title":"Event-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Event-driven programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_driven_programming"},{"title":"Event-driven process chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_process_chain"},{"title":"Inversion of control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inversion_of_control"},{"title":"Trauma trigger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trauma_trigger"}]

Based on the web search results, I found relevant information about event-triggered control:

Event-triggered systems are a field of study focused on analysis and design, as recognized by IEEE fellow Maurice Heemels for his contributions to this area. Event-triggered control is a control methodology that differs from traditional time-triggered approaches.

In contrast to time-triggered systems, which execute tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule, event-triggered control systems respond dynamically to specific events rather than operating on a fixed time schedule.

The concept relates to broader event-driven architectures, where an event can be defined as "a significant change in state", and an event-driven system typically consists of event emitters (or agents), event consumers (or sinks), and event channels, where emitters have the responsibility to detect, gather, and transfer events.

Event-triggered control has applications in various fields including control systems, embedded systems, and networked control, where the system responds to specific triggering conditions rather than operating on a predetermined schedule.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Markov chain switching"

Links: [{"title":"Markov switching multifractal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_switching_multifractal"},{"title":"Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain"},{"title":"Continuous-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Reversible-jump Markov chain Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reversible-jump_Markov_chain_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Markovian arrival process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markovian_arrival_process"},{"title":"Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_model"},{"title":"Discrete-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Absorbing Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absorbing_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Examples of Markov chains - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Examples_of_Markov_chains"},{"title":"Variable-order Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variable-order_Markov_model"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Markov chain switching:

## Key Concepts

Regime-switching models of business cycles were popularized by James D. Hamilton (1989), who used a Markov chain to model switches between periods of high and low GDP growth (or, alternatively, economic expansions and recessions).

## Markov Switching Multifractal (MSM)

One important application is the Markov Switching Multifractal model. In financial econometrics, the Markov-switching multifractal (MSM) is a model of asset returns developed by Laurent E. Calvet and Adlai J. Fisher that incorporates stochastic volatility components of heterogeneous durations.(no content)The Markov switching multifractal model of Laurent E. Calvet and Adlai J. Fisher builds upon the convenience of earlier regime-switching models and uses an arbitrarily large Markov chain to drive the level of volatility of asset returns.

## Practical Applications

In currency and equity series, MSM compares favorably with standard volatility models such as GARCH(1,1) and FIGARCH both in- and out-of-sample, and is used by practitioners in the financial industry for different types of forecasts.

In essence, "Markov chain switching" refers to models that use Markov chains to represent transitions between different regimes or states, commonly used in economics and finance to model shifts in market conditions, volatility, or economic growth rates.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Time delay systems"

Links: [{"title":"Delay differential equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delay_differential_equation"},{"title":"Shapiro time delay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapiro_time_delay"},{"title":"Time-variant system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-variant_system"},{"title":"Time-invariant system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-invariant_system"},{"title":"Busy waiting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Busy_waiting"},{"title":"Signal processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_processing"},{"title":"List of Laplace transforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Laplace_transforms"},{"title":"Group delay and phase delay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_delay_and_phase_delay"},{"title":"Response time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Response_time"},{"title":"Access time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Access_time"}]

Here are the search results for "Time delay systems":

## Overview

Time delay systems, also known as delay differential equations (DDEs), are a type of differential equation in which the derivative of the unknown function at a certain time is given in terms of the values of the function at previous times.

## Applications and Importance

Actuators, sensors, and communication networks that are now involved in feedback control loops introduce such delays.(no content)Besides actual delays, time lags are frequently used to simplify very high order models.(no content)The interest for DDEs keeps on growing in all scientific areas, especially in control engineering.

## Control Challenges

Delay systems are resistant to many classical controllers, and ignoring effects which are adequately represented by DDEs is not a general alternative—in the best situation with constant and known delays, it leads to the same degree of complexity in the control design.(no content)In worst cases with time-varying delays, ignoring them is potentially disastrous in terms of stability and oscillations.

## Solution Methods

DDEs are mostly solved in a stepwise fashion with a principle called the method of steps.(no content)Similar to ordinary differential equations (ODEs), many properties of linear DDEs can be characterized and analyzed using the characteristic equation.

Links: [{"title":"Delay differential equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delay_differential_equation"},{"title":"Shapiro time delay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapiro_time_delay"},{"title":"Time-variant system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-variant_system"},{"title":"Time-invariant system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-invariant_system"},{"title":"Busy waiting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Busy_waiting"},{"title":"Signal processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_processing"},{"title":"List of Laplace transforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Laplace_transforms"},{"title":"Group delay and phase delay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_delay_and_phase_delay"},{"title":"Response time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Response_time"},{"title":"Access time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Access_time"}]

Here are the search results for "Time delay systems":

## Overview

Time delay systems, also known as delay differential equations (DDEs), are a type of differential equation in which the derivative of the unknown function at a certain time is given in terms of the values of the function at previous times.

## Applications and Importance

Actuators, sensors, and communication networks that are now involved in feedback control loops introduce such delays.(no content)Besides actual delays, time lags are frequently used to simplify very high order models.(no content)The interest for DDEs keeps on growing in all scientific areas, especially in control engineering.

## Control Challenges

Delay systems are resistant to many classical controllers, and ignoring effects which are adequately represented by DDEs is not a general alternative—in the best situation with constant and known delays, it leads to the same degree of complexity in the control design.(no content)In worst cases with time-varying delays, ignoring them is potentially disastrous in terms of stability and oscillations.

## Solution Methods

DDEs are mostly solved in a stepwise fashion with a principle called the method of steps.(no content)Similar to ordinary differential equations (ODEs), many properties of linear DDEs can be characterized and analyzed using the characteristic equation.

Gupta - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brij_B._Gupta"},{"title":"Cyber espionage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyber_espionage"},{"title":"Cyberwarfare and Iran - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyberwarfare_by_Iran"},{"title":"Cyber Citizen Shockman Zero - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyber_Citizen_Shockman_Zero"}]

Here are the search results for cyber-physical systems:

## Overview

Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are mechanisms controlled and monitored by computer algorithms, tightly integrated with the internet and its users.(no content)In cyber-physical systems, physical and software components are deeply intertwined, able to operate on different spatial and temporal scales, exhibit multiple and distinct behavioral modalities, and interact with each other in ways that change with context.

## Key Characteristics

CPS involves transdisciplinary approaches, merging theory of cybernetics, mechatronics, design and process science.(no content)CPS is similar to the Internet of Things (IoT), sharing the same basic architecture; nevertheless, CPS presents a higher combination and coordination between physical and computational elements.

## Applications

Examples of CPS include smart grid, autonomous automobile systems, medical monitoring, industrial control systems, robotics systems, recycling and automatic pilot avionics.

## Design Considerations

Unlike more traditional embedded systems, a full-fledged CPS is typically designed as a network of interacting elements with physical input and output instead of as standalone devices.(no content)A challenge in the development of embedded and cyber-physical systems is the large differences in the design practice between the various engineering disciplines involved, such as software and mechanical engineering. Additionally, as of today there is no "language" in terms of design practice that is common to all the involved disciplines in CPS.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov stability"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of Lyapunov stability based on the search results:

## Definition and Basic Concept

Lyapunov stability ensures that near a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable, the system remains stable under small disturbances. More specifically, Lyapunov stability means that if the system starts in a state different from zero in some domain D, then the state will remain in D for all time.

## Historical Background

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## Types of Stability

Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium. Additionally, there is exponential stability, which is an even stronger form of stability.

## Lyapunov Functions

Lyapunov functions are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ordinary differential equation.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Applications

Lyapunov stability has wide-ranging applications. Interest in the "Second Method of Lyapunov" skyrocketed during the Cold War period when it was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities. Additionally, the concept of the Lyapunov exponent has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Links: [{"title":"SQL injection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL_injection"},{"title":"Code injection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_injection"},{"title":"Fault injection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_injection"},{"title":"Packet injection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packet_injection"},{"title":"Man-in-the-middle attack - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man-in-the-middle_attack"},{"title":"Differential fault analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_attack"},{"title":"Data dredging - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_snooping"},{"title":"Data breach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_breaches"},{"title":"Content Security Policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_Security_Policy"},{"title":"TCP sequence prediction attack - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TCP_sequence_prediction_attack"}]

Based on the web search results, I found information related to data injection attacks, though the results primarily focus on related attack types rather than a specific attack category called "False Data Injection Attacks." Here's what I found:

## Data Injection Attack Overview

The search results cover several types of injection attacks:

**SQL Injection**: SQL injection is a code injection technique used to attack data-driven applications, in which malicious SQL statements are inserted into an entry field for execution. SQL injection attacks allow attackers to spoof identity, tamper with existing data, cause repudiation issues such as voiding transactions or changing balances, allow the complete disclosure of all data on the system, destroy the data or make it otherwise unavailable, and become administrators of the database server.

**Code Injection Generally**: Code injection is a computer security exploit where a program fails to correctly process external data, such as user input, causing it to interpret the data as executable commands. An attacker using this method "injects" code into the program while it is running.

**Packet Injection**: Packet injection in computer networking is the process of interfering with an established network connection by means of constructing packets to appear as if they are part of the normal communication stream. The packet injection process allows an unknown third party to disrupt or intercept packets from the consenting parties that are communicating, which can lead to degradation or blockage of users' ability to utilize certain network services or protocols.

If you're looking for more specific information about "False Data Injection Attacks" in a particular context (such as power systems, critical infrastructure, or specific security domains), I'd be happy to search for that with additional details.

The search results cover several types of injection attacks:

**SQL Injection**: SQL injection is a code injection technique used to attack data-driven applications, in which malicious SQL statements are inserted into an entry field for execution. SQL injection attacks allow attackers to spoof identity, tamper with existing data, cause repudiation issues such as voiding transactions or changing balances, allow the complete disclosure of all data on the system, destroy the data or make it otherwise unavailable, and become administrators of the database server.

**Code Injection Generally**: Code injection is a computer security exploit where a program fails to correctly process external data, such as user input, causing it to interpret the data as executable commands. An attacker using this method "injects" code into the program while it is running.

**Packet Injection**: Packet injection in computer networking is the process of interfering with an established network connection by means of constructing packets to appear as if they are part of the normal communication stream. The packet injection process allows an unknown third party to disrupt or intercept packets from the consenting parties that are communicating, which can lead to degradation or blockage of users' ability to utilize certain network services or protocols.

If you're looking for more specific information about "False Data Injection Attacks" in a particular context (such as power systems, critical infrastructure, or specific security domains), I'd be happy to search for that with additional details.

I've completed a web search for "Finite-time stability control." Based on the search results, I found general information about control theory and stability concepts, though the results don't contain specific details focused directly on "finite-time stability" as a dedicated topic.

From the search results, I can provide some relevant context:

**Related Stability Concepts:**

In asymptotically stable control systems, the variables always decrease from their initial value and do not show permanent oscillations. However, finite-time stability is a different concept—it focuses on systems reaching a desired state in a finite amount of time rather than asymptotically approaching it.

A notable property of nonlinear systems is that solutions of nonlinear systems may not exist for all times, which is related to the phenomenon of "finite escape time" in nonlinear dynamics.

**Control Methods:**

The search results mention several advanced control techniques that could be applied to finite-time stability problems, including Sliding mode control (SMC) developed by Vadim Utkin, which is actually a technique often used in finite-time control applications.

For more detailed and specific information about finite-time stability control methodology, techniques, and applications, you may want to consult academic papers or specialized control theory resources, as this is an advanced research topic that may not be thoroughly covered in general Wikipedia articles.

Web search results for query: "Vertical takeoff landing aircraft"

Links: [{"title":"V/STOL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V/STOL"},{"title":"List of VTOL aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_VTOL_aircraft"},{"title":"eVTOL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EVTOL"},{"title":"Takeoff and landing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takeoff_and_landing"},{"title":"VTOL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_take-off_and_landing"},{"title":"VTVL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VTVL"},{"title":"Bell X-14 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_X-14"},{"title":"Dassault Mirage IIIV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dassault_Mirage_IIIV"},{"title":"Takeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takeoff"},{"title":"Yakovlev Yak-141 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yakovlev_Yak-141"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about vertical takeoff and landing aircraft:

## Definition and Overview

A vertical and/or short take-off and landing (V/STOL) aircraft is an airplane able to take off or land vertically or on short runways.(no content)Vertical takeoff and landing (VTOL) aircraft are a subset of V/STOL craft that do not require runways at all.

## Types of VTOL Aircraft

Besides the ubiquitous helicopters, there are currently two types of VTOL aircraft in military service: tiltrotor aircraft, such as the Bell Boeing V-22 Osprey, and thrust-vectoring airplanes, such as the Harrier family and new F-35B Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter (JSF).(no content)In 2018 Opener Aero demonstrated an electrically powered fixed-wing VTOL aircraft, the Blackfly, which the manufacturer claims is the world's first ultralight fixed-wing, all-electric, vertical take-off and landing aircraft.

## Emerging Technology

Electric vertical takeoff and landing aircraft, or eVTOLs, are being developed along with more autonomous flight control technologies and mobility-as-a-service (MaaS) to enable advanced air mobility (AAM), that could include on-demand air taxi services, regional air mobility, freight delivery, and personal air vehicles (PAVs).

## Historical Development

Manned VTOL aircraft, in the form of primitive helicopters, first flew in 1907, but would take until after World War Two to be perfected.(no content)The Bell-Boeing V-22 Osprey is considered the world's first production tiltrotor aircraft.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary:

## Paper Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Type:** Contribution

**Key Findings:**
The paper presents a novel contribution to finite-time event-triggered control for cyber-physical systems under security attacks. It proposes 8 key technologies and methodologies:

### Technologies Identified:
1. **Event-driven architecture** (proposes) - The paper's core contribution, replacing traditional time-triggered control
2. **Markov chain** (uses) - Models state transitions in semi-Markovian switching systems
3. **Cyber-physical system** (uses) - The application domain for the control problem
4. **Man-in-the-middle attack** (uses) - Context for false data injection attack modeling
5. **Lyapunov stability** (uses) - Foundation for stability analysis using Lyapunov-Krasovskii functionals
6. **Delay differential equation** (uses) - Models network-induced delays in the control system
7. **Vertical take-off and landing** (uses) - Application example using VTOL helicopter dynamics
8. **Control theory** (uses) - The theoretical framework for controller synthesis

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully
- 8 triples extracted
- Entity types properly distributed (4 concepts, 1 task, 2 methods, 1 artifact)
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid
- At least 1 "proposes" relation confirmed for contribution paper
- All "uses" relations present as required

The triples_output.json file has been updated and validated.
